g.text: By deﬁnition, the CCF is a real-valued function, so its Fourier components satisfy the condition
, where the asterisk denotes the complex conjugate. In the simplest case of
, the deﬁnition of the CCF implies that it is an even function, i.e.,
so only cosine terms are present in the Fourier series, see Equation (12):
contain valuable information about the symmetry of the
systemand are directly related to the Fourier components of the scattered intensity
Direct comparison of Equations (6), (7), (13) reveals that for
CCF are related to the BOorder parameters as
Thus, the values of the BO order parameters can be directly evaluated by ACXXA.
One may consider ensemble-averaged values of the CCF or its Fourier components over many
system. We should note that direct averaging of the 2D di
may lead to smearing of the signal, for example, in the case when the patterns di
only by rotation around the central point
0. At the same time, averaging of the CCFs would lead
to an enhancement of the symmetry features of the di
raction patterns, while the experimental noise
will be reduced. Angular anisotropies in X-ray or electron di
raction patterns may be analyzed as well
by the multipole expansion of Legendre polynomials as suggested in reference [
To illustrate the type of problems which can be addressed by AXCCA, let us consider X-ray
scattering from an ensemble of identical particles randomly oriented in space. First of all, one can
recover the structure of an individual particle by analyzing the di
of particles with a uniform distribution of orientations [
simpliﬁed if one can neglect the interference between the di
which is possible if the transverse coherence length of X-rays is smaller than the typical interparticle
]. This corresponds to the case of a “dilute solution” in conventional scattering theory for
liquids or small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), when the structure factor simply equals to unity.
The second type of problems is related to the quantitative description of the orientational
correlation of particles. This includes both, the characterization of orientational distribution of particles
] as well as the bond-orientational order in dense systems [
case, studies of the bond-orientational order necessarily include interference of the scattered X-rays
], which can signiﬁcantly complicate the analysis. Atypical example of
such a systemis the hexatic phase in LCs, which will be considered in the following section.
